Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Using Stable Isotopes to Constrain the Atmospheric Carbon Monoxide Budget over the Last 20,000 Years
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mak/1443482

This project will compare current atmospheric conditions with those of the remote past prior to human influence. This is important in order to understand the impact of human activities on Earth's atmosphere, and to determine the stability of the composition of the atmosphere in the past. How humans have impacted Earth?s atmospheric composition is important for developing accurate predictions of future global atmospheric conditions. In addition to training students, the investigators will support continuing education of high school science teachers on Long Island through specifically tailored, interactive seminars on various topics in earth science, atmospheric sciences, physics and biology. A pilot program at Mount Sinai School District, near Stony Brook University will be the first implementation of this program.

The investigators plan to reconstruct historical variations in the sources of atmospheric carbon monoxide (CO) from measurements of the concentration and stable isotopic abundance of carbon monoxide ([CO], 13CO and C18O) in the South Pole Ice Core, which is being drilled in 2014-2016. The goal is to strategically sample and reconstruct the relative variations in CO source strengths over the past 20,000 years. These will be the first measurements to extend the CO record beyond 650 years before present, back to the last glacial maximum. Both atmospheric chemical processes and variations in CO sources can impact the CO budget, and variations in the CO budget are useful in identifying and quantifying chemistry-climate interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this project, the PI and his students analyzed ice core samples collected from the South Pole for the isotopic composition of atmospheric carbon monoxide. The goal was to go back in time, up to 20,000 years before present (BP), so see what trends, or changes, if any, in the atmosphere were reflected by atmospheric carbon monoxide or its isotopes. 

There is a reason to think that the isotopes of CO may change over time, because the sources of CO include biomass burning and hydrocarbon oxidation, both of which occurred prior to the industrial revolution. However since these measurements are extremely difficult to make, no measurements from ice have been published since this PI presented a record going back 700 years. In this work the PI's group analyzed samples dating back about 8000 years; the older samples were to be analyzed by the team at the University of Rochester (this is a collaborative proposal).

Our findings are the first of their kind, thus there is no record with which a direct comparison can be made. Nevertheless the results indicate that the concentration of atmospheric CO has been relatively stable over the past 8000 years; and there is a negative trend in both the oxygen isotope composition and the carbon isotope composition. This may indicate a long term trend in the oxidation state of the atmosphere; in other words the indication is that there has been a decrease in burning sources over the past 8000 years. We are currently completing paleoclimate analyses with a simple model to help interpret the observations. Two manuscripts are currently being written.

Under this award, two PhD students were supported. One of them is now a faculty member in the chemistry department at a major research university, where she teaches upper division spectroscopy courses and serves as a mentor to women in science.
